title-group.article-title: Life-Threatening Cytomegalovirus Enteritis and Pneumonia in an Immunocompetent Adolescent
title-group.subtitle: A Case Report and Brief Literature Review

article-meta.aff: 1University of Mississippi Health Center, Jackson, MS, USA

author-notes.corresp: Michael J. Nowicki, Division of Pediatric Gastroenterology, University of Mississippi Health Center, 2500 North State Street, Jackson, MS 39216, USA Email: mnowicki@umc.edu

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a nearly ubiquitous human pathogen in the herpes virus family that has been reported to be infectious in up to 100% of adults by the age of 30 years.1 The majority of CMV infections occur in the perinatal period, infancy, or early adulthood and are asymptomatic or present as a mononucleosis-like syndrome2 with gastrointestinal (GI) disease being exceedingly rare.3 However, severe infections are known to present in immunocompromised patients, with GI manifestations being among the most commonly reported.4 Patients with primary immune deficiencies, AIDS, organ transplantation, chemotherapy, and prolonged steroid use have all been shown to be at increased risk for CMV infection, particularly CMV colitis.3 It was believed that CMV colitis in the immunocompetent patient was an extremely rare occurrence, but recent literature suggests the prevalence is higher than previously suspected, although the incidence in the pediatric population remains sparse.

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: A 16-year-old Native American female with no significant past medical history presented as a transfer from an outside community hospital with a 3-week history of vomiting and diarrhea. During this time she also reported diffuse, colicky abdominal pain, anorexia, weight loss (12 kg), and decreased energy. She had been evaluated twice at a local clinic and was diagnosed with gastroenteritis. Because of persistent symptoms, she was admitted to the community hospital for treatment of dehydration. Initial laboratory studies were normal, including complete blood count, liver panel, and coagulation studies. Despite aggressive fluid support the patient developed worsening dehydration prompting transfer to the pediatric intensive care unit at our institution.

On arrival the patient appeared ill. Vital signs showed tachycardia (heart rate 117) and mild hypertension (135/78 mm Hg). Mucous membranes were tacky. Cardiovascular exam showed no murmur. The abdominal exam showed a protuberant abdomen with active bowel sounds, diffuse pain to palpation without guarding or rebound, and no organomegaly. Rectal exam showed no fissure, fistulae, or tags; there was a copious amount of liquid stool that was occult blood positive. Admission laboratory studies included serum electrolytes, liver panel, urine pregnancy test, and stool studies (bacterial culture, enterovirus culture, Clostridium difficile toxins A and B, Cryptosporidium antigen, Giardia antigen, Rotavirus antigen) were normal. Complete blood count showed normal white blood cell count (8900/mm3) and platelet count (231 000/mm3); there was a mild microcytic anemia (hemoglobin 9.8 g/dL; hematocrit 29.5%; mean corpuscular volume 73.9 fL). The stool contained numerous white blood cells. The patient received intravenous fluids, anti-emetics, and pantoprazole for ulcer prophylaxis. Her condition improved overnight and she was transferred to the general floor. She was started on nitazoxanide empirically, resulting in a decrease in diarrhea, improved appetite, and resolution of emesis. However, she developed cough and fever; a chest X-ray revealed pneumonia, for which she was started on antibiotic therapy with ceftriaxone and azithromycin. On the third day of admission, the patient had worsening diarrhea with return of abdominal pain and vomiting. Repeat laboratory studies showed no significant changes in serum electrolytes or complete blood count. A liver panel revealed evidence of hepatitis with elevation of AST (246 U/L) and ALT (224 U/L). An abdominal ultrasound showed mild hepatosplenomegally and findings consistent with mild fatty liver. Further investigation for an etiology of both diarrhea and hepatitis included testing for CMV. Stool culture for CMV and antibody to CMV (IgG and IgM) were positive, whereas quantitative polymerase chain reaction and urine culture for CMV were negative. The patient continued to have diarrhea and abdominal pain complicated by transient hyponatremia. Because of persistent diarrhea of unclear etiology esophagogastroduodenoscopy and colonoscopy were performed, revealing grossly normal appearing mucosa (Figure 1). However, biopsies revealed CMV inclusions in the esophagus, gastric fundus, and duodenal bulb (Figure 2). Her abdominal pain and diarrhea persisted, necessitating continued intravenous fluids and slow advancement of oral feeding.

caption.p: The mucosa of the esophagus (A), stomach (B), and duodenum (C) appeared normal grossly.

A, The esophageal biopsy showed chronic esophagitis with submucosal cells containing intranuclear inclusions consistent with cytomegalovirus (CMV) cytopathic effect. B, Immunohistochemical stain for CMV was positive. C, The gastric body showed moderately severe active chronic gastritis with numerous gastric epithelial cells and one stromal cell containing intranuclear inclusions consistent with CMV cytopathic effect. D, The duodenum showed chronic duodenitis with moderate villous atrophy. One Brunner’s gland epithelial cell contained intranuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions consistent with CMV cytopathic effect. The arrow points to CMV inclusions.

sec.p: On the 23rd day of admission, the patient experienced acute deterioration in clinical status manifested by high grade fever (Tmax = 103°F), respiratory distress, decreased oxygen saturation, hyponatremia, and metabolic acidosis. She was transferred to the intensive care unit and started on intravenous gancyclovir. Symptoms did not improve significantly, and on the 30th day of admission the patient developed worsening respiratory distress with increasing oxygen requirement requiring intubation and mechanical ventilation. A repeat chest X-ray revealed pneumonia and broad spectrum antibiotic coverage with vancomycin and levofloxacin was initiated. Bronchosopy was performed; bronchial lavage cultures grew CMV. The patient showed slow clinical improvement, was extubated, and transferred to the general ward. GI symptoms slowly resolved and the patient was able to tolerate a full diet.

An evaluation for an underlying immunodeficiency was undertaken. Laboratory studies included human immunodeficiency virus antibody (negative), quantitative immunoglobulins (IgG 3190 mg/dL [normal 700-1600 mg/dL], IgA 408 mg/dL [normal 70-400 mg/dL], IgM 432 mg/dl [normal 40-230 mg/dL]), CH50 (normal), white blood cells (6100/mm3, 54% segmented neutrophils, 30% lymphocytes, 14% monocytes, 1% eosinophils, and 1% basophils). T-cell subsets revealed a decrease in CD4 counts (16%, normal 37% to 48%), an increase in CD8 counts (59%, normal 25% to 31%), and a decrease in the CD4:CD8 ratio (0.2, normal 1.05 to 2.61). Although the initial evaluation showed aberrations in T-cell subsets, they normalized with resolution of the CMV infection. The patient was discharged on the 50th day to complete 6 weeks of ganciclovir. She has remained well during the follow-up period of 9 months.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: CMV is a common human infection as evidenced by seroprevalence rates of 40% to 100% in adults.1 Most primary infections occur early in life and are asymptomatic or present as a mild mononucleosis-like syndrome.2,5 Following acute infection, CMV becomes latent, putting the host at risk for recurrence. Reactivation is typically associated with immune dysfunction including congenital or acquired immune deficiency, transplant recipients, immunosuppressant therapy, and immune modulating diseases (diabetes mellitus, age >55 years, renal failure, malignancy, lupus).2,4,6,7 However, disease due to CMV reactivation does occur in immunocompetent individuals. In a large prospective study of nearly 8000 immunocompetent adults, disease due to CMV was found in 1.6%; the most common presentation being hepatitis (28%).8 In another study addressing GI involvement specifically, GI biopsies from unselected patients were screened for the presence of CMV; the overall prevalence of infection was 0.9%.9 In this study, the majority of patients with CMV were immunocompromised (69%), whereas 31% were immunocompetent.9 Pediatric patients constitute a small percentage of reported cases of CMV disease in immunocompetent patients.4,7,8,10,11

CMV disease can occur anywhere within the alimentary canal12-14; the most commonly involved site being the colon.3,4,7,12 Small bowel involvement is relatively rare, with the distal small bowel being more commonly involved then the upper small bowel.12,15 Symptoms depend on the location of the disease within the GI tract, as well as confounding factors in immunocompromised patients. Commonly described symptoms and signs are nonspecific, including fever, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, weight loss, abdominal pain, diarrhea, hematochezia, melena, and perforation.4 Endoscopic findings are typically represented by erosions, ulcerations, or hemorrhage of the mucosa3,9,10; rarely the mucosa may only appear erythematous, edematous, or normal.10,16,17

CMV inclusion bodies and/or positive immunohistochemical staining for CMV antigen on biopsy are considered the gold standard for diagnosing CMV enterocolitis.3 Supportive tests include serum anti-CMV antibodies (IgG and IgM), blood culture, stool culture, and oropharnygeal culture.3 Polymerase chain reaction is highly specific, but because of the transient nature of the viremia, a sample collected during time of dormancy for the virus can lead to false negative results.18 The patient described herein had CMV confirmed by the presence of inclusion bodies on mucosal biopsy, a positive stool culture, and positive serologic testing for CMV antibodies (IgM and IgG). Although CMV inclusion bodies can be present in infection without overt disease,3 the marked improvement seen in our patient following treatment with ganciclovir supports a diagnosis of CMV-induced enteritis.

Investigation for an underlying immune deficiency in our patient was negative. However, an aberration in T-cell expression was noted with a decrease in T-helper cells, an increase in T suppressor-cytotoxic cells, and a reversal of the normal CD4:CD8 ratio. Follow-up studies performed 5 weeks after initiation of treatment showed near normalization of T-cell status. The finding of transient T-cell suppression during acute CMV infection, with subsequent normalization with improved clinical status, has been previously reported.19 Previous studies have shown that the risk for CMV colitis in immunocompromised individuals, particularly those with AIDS, directly correlates with decreased T-helper counts.20

CMV disease in immunocompetent patients is almost always self-limited, requiring only supportive care.3 Also, patients receiving immunosuppressant medications (corticosteroids, cancer chemotherapy, transplant recipients) have resolution of CMV infection if their medications can be decreased or stopped.3 GI CMV disease in sustained immunodeficiency has a high mortality rate if not treated.3 Predictors of increased mortality include advanced age, comorbid diagnoses, multi-organ involvement, and hospital-acquired infection.8,11

However, in severe disease, regardless of underlying immune status, antiviral therapy may be warranted.10,21 The drug of choice for severe CMV-induced colitis is gancyclovir for 2 to 6 weeks based on resolution of clinical signs and symptoms.3,4,8,11,18 Foscarnet may be used as a second-line agent but carries a higher risk for renal dysfunction and electrolyte abnormalities.3 Documenting resolution is possible by repeat colonoscopic biopsy or stool culture; however, it is typically not necessary.

In conclusion, we report an immunocompetent child who developed significant CMV enterocolitis requiring treatment with antiviral medication. CMV infection was entertained after more common etiologic organisms were excluded. Similar to previously reported patients, the patient described herein had a transient aberration in T-cell subsets. Despite its extreme rarity within the pediatric population, CMV infection should be considered in children with enteritis when more common etiologies have been excluded. A higher index of suspicion is indicated in immunocompromised patients; however, CMV colitis can be seen in individuals with normal immune function. Therapy is typically confined to supportive care, with antiviral treatment reserved for those with severe disease.
